title: Managing research institute

author: Tamara Lah Turnšek, National Institute of Biology

segmentation: It's my pleasure to introduce the model.

Actual check tomorrow is not only a researcher and professor at University of Indiana, she's also president of Slovenian National Committee for Promoting Women in Science and actually now he's standing in front of us as being director of National Institute of Biology of Slovenia.
So thank you for introducing me.
Unfortunately, I didn't make my Mail.
My slides on time.
Ann, not my CV, so I'll just tell you more about me and more about the work that we're doing along with the slides.
Of course, I'm the one I'm the person that cannot talk without slides, so just the other extreme perhaps and.
As well, I have to thank do not to invite me here and my talk will first really introduce myself and what I feel when I'm doing things that I'm doing in my everyday life.
And the second part will be dedicated or will be actually the.
Presentation that I had during this European Presidency.
As you all know Salinas, now for half a year holding this presidency and there was one important meeting for us and this was the so-called Crest meeting when that was dedicated to.
What they called out the title was very good family oriented research area, so it's not talking about women.
And I think this is right because it we have to include men into this movement.
Absolutely, they are needed to support us, otherwise we would fail in our universal whatever goes we have.
And so the second part really will be more or less telling you what we presented there and how we actually.

Slovenia has a certain special perhaps position between eastern and Western Europe and how we kind of presented a model, a Slovenian model perhaps, which of course has roots already in the former Yugoslavia, as we heard from Tatiana, and I think that was a very nice would be a very nice comparison of what the experience we had, or together in the previous Yugoslavia.
But let's meet, let me start with our Institute, which is located really at the outskirts of Ljubljana.
Below are organic and how I became a director.
My career started here.
Actually read at this institution your Steven Institute when I was a research assistant.
And of course I did a lot of lab workers or lab assistance in the field of natural and technical Sciences.
Do what you have to really first learn how to do science.
Learn the research methodology, learn how to read the papers.
And then later on do your own thinking and producing your own results.
You learn how to put the hypothesis from this data and how to publish papers, and then you progress through the your careers and then you start writing the grants.
And then you also try to organize people around yourself to become a leader of a group larger or smaller, and you develop your skills specially.
In decision making, how to communicate?

Also this is very important and then of course you have to take a load of a lot, a lot of administration and then you become a director so I don't know if this is good or red and I don't know if everybody wants this because the administration is something that nobody know.
Research that I know of likes but.
You just have to take in and.
What skills do we need?
What kind of person is becoming a director?
It's has a special knowledge.
Of course knowledge is important, but that's what everybody can acquire.
Then some talents, some skills and some training which are here and they have to all interact.
So of course, as you have to be relatively good scientist, you had to also learn other skills, not only your profession.
You have to be broader.
You have to also perhaps have some talent or you acquire skills in managing, or you learn something from from the literature or courses and you have to be fit not only physically.

I mean psychologically, and this is very important to be strong and you have to have a kind of thinking that's a network sinking in here this, I think is a core is the key element that makes also women very, very suitable an fit for this positions.
Also, because they women are also from history or society or from everyday life really are psychologists.
They educate children, they understand children, they listen to the children and they acquire emotional intelligence which either they have been born with or they just acquired.
During life and so nobody has all this knowledge in all these fields, but one can have a little bit of each of this kind of knowledge skills to become.
Director so, but the major quality for woman is really flexibility not to think only in terms of 1 discipline but many disciplines.
You have to integrate various various knowledge.
Where is skills then you have to really be curious.
You have to find another pathways, be creative and then you have to.
Also have skills for communicating.
This is really important and I think This is why or what do men have a lot and then ambition in constant learning, specially an ambition in getting higher position for many reasons.
Be good listener and this is what also women are.
So then finally you also have to be make capable making fast decisions but you have to make clear decisions.
And you have to think about the decisions before, so that's how I came.
First, the group leader at at the same time.
Also the director of this Institute, and this is my group today.
So is it any special about we make a woman or man?
Each woman or men can probably with this kind of skills or this kind of talents, or whatever ambition and energy reach this goal, but why women don't?
At the moment?
However, in Slovenia, this station is much better.
Out of 15 research institutes, there are six women directors already, so we are coming very close to half half what I think is a very good sign that we are moving towards the.
So that we have.
Of course you cannot forget that you are a woman, so you should remain woman.
You should not surrender and behavior command.
I mean, this is not leading anywhere and this is my experience.
You have to remain a woman which is hard.
Specially not so much in SoC.
SoC accepted my career very well actually.
The problem was at work.
As I mentioned I started to work here at this Institute that was very male oriented at the time when I.
Move to become more 1520 years ago.
Even not so much now because now it's a big progress.
Also here there are many heads of the departments laboratories.
At that time there was practically none and so the atmosphere right in this building where we are now was very chilly as Martha said or somebody else got this.
This expression really?
Anecdote of this might be that at that time I was.
Also, doing some promotion for the Institute I was editor of the newspaper of the Institute and then a Nobel laureate came to visit the Institute and they had a big lecture or full.

The theater was awful and then they invited him on a business meeting and I wanted to be present because I would like to read something about it and then the the time the director said, well you can come, you will be a nice decoration for the business meeting.
So that was the attitude and I think I was really very very.

Angry at him and later on I also explain him that this is not the way how to behave, but that how it was, so I moved them from this Institute to another Institute which is biology and there the racial or the they actually.
There are 2/3 of women and now an already.
At that time there was more of a balance between men and women and the atmosphere was totally different.
In addition to that, I really try to create family friendly or.
Agreement, friendly atmosphere and now we're even too many, but that's another problem.
And then at home.
Of course, a woman cannot succeed in the career.
I think if the family is not supporting, we heard your story, which is hard.
My story was a little more.
Kind of nicer the beginning, but when I progressed I had parents and husband who supported me.

But today I'm divorced, so maybe that there's just something and it was perhaps due to the fact that you really split your interest between moon between between work and family and some and redant like it too much.
Then of course this is a problem that we can talk about later.

Now I'm switching to the other part of this talk, and this is the showing you the presentation that actually resulted from common efforts of all these ladies listed here, and some of them are member of our National Committee for four Complicated for enhancement of the role of women in Science, which I used to be chair, but I'm kind of.
Having too many obligations, so I hope the committee will get a very energetic new chair in near future.
So what we presented was first that we wanted to present a broader societal environment and then give some figures of where we are at the moment.
In Slovenia with respect to really statistics and data on women in science, and then give some recommendation not only for Slovenia but or European.
Or, let's say general, that would also hold be true for United States, for example, that we heard of today.
So we actually can divide our history into what happened before 1990 and what happened after that.
But to start with, with immediately after the Second World War, we were actually very slow in getting the Constitution grants.
The constitutional equal equality for men and women.
This was only after the Second World War.
If this is late, for also other European countries compared to other European countries.
And at that time, of course we had this self management system and we already heard that in Yugoslavia under the system, there were a lot of actually freedom.
Specially Slovenia was very much oriented to the West.
There was a also the importance of science and the recognition of scientists was better than now.
And we got also a lot of the time legal acts that contributed to work, family harmonization.
As you can see here already.
At that time there was a paid maternity leave, prolonged to a one year.
What, as you have heard today is not heard of.
For example in United States or many other European Western European countries so called.
Western European country.
Then of course at that time we were open to also to discuss the problems and this is a slide that I got.

Actually from Mata, who already at that time was telling that a lot of problems, social problems, work problems, women problems were openly discussed in within the Yugoslav SoC and Social Sciences Society social conflicts, but what happened in?
1991 we were all happy to get the first government, Slovenian government, state and so on.
And but what happened?
Actually, the things are not getting better for women, as you will see political framework of course was declaring that science and technology is very important.
Moving towards application.
We had advanced evaluation system but science is still now considered as an expenditure and not as an investment in all.
On all the Western European or let's say industrial countries and this change of the system did not improve social position for women at all and parental leave now is still mainly used by women.
Although we are trying now to implement that also to men and I have to say that now there are men that are also using this.
The parental leave.

And also part time job is still not possible by our legislation on work legislation, child and elder care is not satisfactory as we know there is prices for childcare are increasing in Ljubljana for example which is something that it's on thinkable of and it was not so before work from home is still usually not possible and therefore we are still limited in mobility.
That's a European kind of mobility which is now so.
Well, very much favorite.
Kind of wanted from the EU from the Brussels.
So, um.

There was something, but was also very good at the time and I'm coming to this later on and this is the project of young researchers at the time it was recognized and this was still in in self management system.
So got where science was important as I said and they recognize that we need more scientists.
We need more researchers and therefore the government decided to to.

Implement this this project 2003 or I don't know how many researchers until 2000 and this is now prolonged and this is very good and it's unique in Europe because they or even in other countries or Japan or I don't know United States because what government pays is not only the fellowship, but it pays the whole salary and the research expenses as well as travel expenses.
And also what is very important.
This young people are included in the research teams.
As fully, fully, fully employed and they feel part of the team and that's why they are more productive and successful.

And it's also providing kind of Social Security and the effect of this is the side effect that was not thought of before is was that there was more women in science enrolled in science doing science started PhD.
And I will show you.
Some data later on, so in conclusion to this part in Slovenia, as in many former communist and socialist countries.

There was a policy of early integration of women in workforce market and that let initially to relatively better situation that we had in the eastern countries of Europe then compared to other more industrial countries where women have in many countries not yet fully achieved.
Integration into scientific in higher educational institutions and due to later political events, Slovenia somehow positioned itself in still remains in the middle between Western.
And Eastern UU countries and all the statistical data you can look out at the publication.
She figures this is a publication that is issued by brushes Brussels Committee, Helsinki, Groupon and I think it's in group's condition is then.
This will show that Slovenia is really right in them.
So also in the proportion of young or female researchers, for example, this is from 2003.
If here it is EUU 25 this is the average of European or broader European or European country Slovenia is somehow here, so it's right in the middle.
Anne.
And now what is happening now?
Well, it looks like we're not very happy still.
As we set young Krisha Young researchers project really increased highly the.
Graduate students and if you look at this curve from 1950 up to now, these are the one that graduated to see that already.
Here we reached 5050 graduated but this project young researchers started here some from here on there is a tremendous increase in Masters thesis and in PhD thesis.
And as you can see now at the moment they are already nearly 50% of doctors.
Conduct rates that are women, so this is something that it's it's not reached in many European countries.
However, as you can see here, the number of full professors in academia, faculties in Slovenia is very low.
It's actually decreasing now in this.
After 1991, however, the positions of full professors or equivalent positions at the Research Institute.
Is it?
Increasing so in this point the position the institutes are better off.
So also what we notice doing the statistic at the Ministry of Science is that there are more and more applicants, women, applicants for projects and also there are more and more beneficiaries.
So the success rate, specially in natural Sciences, is improving and exactly will soon become better.
Not to mention that also in terms of graduate students and post graduate students, women are doing better finish with better grades and in.
Earlier so there are better students in short, but again still top positions.
The National Science awards.
Also, as we've heard before, the membership in Slovene Academy of Sciences and Arts advising budding research covers, and these are all men dominated still and men like behavior is expected.
What is really not a good except as I mentioned before, research institutes are doing better.
They are nearly 5050 directors that are female.
So this is less pronounced at the Research Institute as measured.
Before.

One 99 and we are also the member of this Helsinki group that I was telling you about.
This is the group for women in science within the EU.
It's a consulting body.
It's not a decision making body, so it's something there are amendments that they are there actually mandates or recommendation that this group is producing.
But this can may or may not.
Be accepted at the governmental level at any of.
The EU government.
Well, what about payment?
We heard that in United States there's really a big gap between payment and you have to negotiate for your salary.
I had the same experience when I was in the States.
I really this was one to one negotiation and it was.
Depends how good you are.
What kind of tricks to use, and that's how you got your salary.
So here we see that in Slovenia in general in there is let's say 10%.
Only difference between men and women is not.
So bad in fact, but in science we see that there is also in the total gross earning is not.
It's not a lot of difference, but the difference is now increasing when you go to the highest position.
But the difference is really drastic when you dissect this oil salary, total salary into the parts that are that has to be by by law by legislation you know we have the.
All the acts are of course we have equal rights and equal salaries, but then it comes additions to functional supplements.
So this depends on your boss or incentive.
This also depends on your boss, lot of times.

So it's even 50% differences in these are perhaps larger at the full professor position and the.
Academia.
So then we have this legal act.

It's no problem with illegal acts, but in reality there are the subtle discrimination, like for example payments that I just mentioned and so on.
Here we are still a long way to reach the really equal recognition.
We don't have quotas, and as mentioned by the young colleague Tatiana in the United States, I don't know if this is good or bad.
Certainly it has to be very carefully taken, although now some European countries did that.
Some countries do really recommend that, specially we know that Scandinavians.

Examples of how they recruited more women in politics and this may be the same in size, but it is a positive measure which can only be applied for a certain amount of time and then you should stop it.

But when you reach a certain certain level of of equality here also there are problems because in some areas such as Medical Sciences or Biological Sciences or even teaching as we also heard today women predominate.
And this is not good anymore.
So what we want is a really balanced.
It's a teamwork work as work, teamwork of men and women, each contributing equal parts equal, equal, equal talents that they have.

A recruit man in this areas.
